title: Storm clouds gather as man who saved the euro bows out
text:
The defining moment for Mario Draghi as president of the European Central Bank (ECB) came at the fringe of the London Olympics in 2012.

The ferocious debt crisis in Greece had spread to Spain and Italy, yields on government stocks across Europe were soaring and the very future of the single currency – the European Union’s flagship project – looked in jeopardy.

It was at this point the Italian president of the ECB defied the forces of monetary conservatism at the Bundesbank in Germany and vowed to do ‘whatever it takes’ to save the euro.

Hard act to follow: Mario Draghi is to step down as president of the European Central Bank at the end of the month

Those three words revealed Draghi’s unwavering commitment to stand-by the ailing currency – and pulled the eurozone back from the brink.

The threat of a Greek exit – or Grexit – from the European project was averted. Bond yields, the interest rate return on the sovereign debt of eurozone members, subsided.

This led the Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Krugman to describe Draghi as ‘arguably the greatest central banker of modern times’.

Germany battles slump Hopes that Germany will emerge from recession in the run up to Christmas have suffered a setback as it registered the first fall in employment for six years. The job losses, while small, are concentrated in manufacturing, where staffing numbers registered their biggest drop in almost a decade. The country’s Bundesbank this week said Germany had tumbled into recession in the third quarter amid global trade tensions, disruption in the car industry and uncertainty around Brexit. The latest snapshot of Europe’s biggest economy, published yesterday, indicates it has continued to shrink as its manufacturing and services industries have misfired.

Doubtlessly former Fed chairmen Paul Volcker, Alan Greenspan and Ben Bernanke – the latter steered the world clear of the 2008-09 financial crisis – might dispute that.

But there is no denying that the euro area and it institutions, which Draghi hands over to former IMF chief Christine Lagarde at the end of the month, are more solid, durable and able to withstand shocks than they were when he took command in 2011.

That is not to say that the single currency area is an unalloyed triumph. It is anything but as the latest data from the eurozone, showing a weak start to the final quarter of 2019, reveals.

Indeed, the eurozone being inherited by Lagarde has come to look a little like Japan during its lost decades in the latter part of the 20th century and early part of the 21st century.

The region is caught in a trap where a combination of negative interest rates and bond buying, worth €4.65 trillion, together with direct short-term assistance to wobbling banks in Greece, Italy and elsewhere, has just been enough to prevent Europe from slump.

But it is an uphill struggle and the ECB has so far failed to bring inflation back to its 2 per cent target. Although for the moment deflation has been avoided, the inflation rate hovers closer to 1 per cent.

One of Draghi’s last rolls of the dice before he left office was to go deeper into negative interest rates on the grounds that it encourages commerce and citizens to spend rather than leave money in the bank where its value deteriorates.

Successor: Draghi's replacement Christine Lagarde inherits a Eurozone teetering on the brink of recession

His CV illustrates why there is no substitute for frontline experience when it comes to central banking.

That is a lesson which Chancellor Sajid Javid and Downing Street might want to contemplate as a successor is chosen to Mark Carney, who is due to step down as governor of the Bank of England on January 31, 2020 after two Brexit-related extensions to his tenure.

As is the case with Carney and Bill Dudley, former president of the New York Fed, a stint at Goldman Sachs also exposed Draghi to the raw, bonus driven capitalism of the investment banks.

Throughout his period at the ECB he has been in a running battle with German members of the interest rate-setting ECB council as well as the German federal courts, which have challenged the use of ECB funds for rescue operations for the euro area and the banks.

Draghi managed to extend the ECB’s powers, both as a lender of last resort to the financial system and as regulator of the most significant banks.

But the lack of common fiscal policy across the euro area’s 17 members, together with feeble transfers from wealthy to poorer states, has condemned Greece, Spain and Italy to high unemployment levels and undermined social cohesion.

These dangers arose in spite of Draghi’s titanic struggle to secure fundamental change.
